awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Quantum Phase Transitions and Dissipation in Superconducting Nanowires
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Abstract
The goal of this Faculty Early Career Development project at Johns Hopkins University is to investigate the quantum phase transitions and dissipation in superconducting nanowires. A quantum phase transition can be observed close to absolute zero temperature when some critical parameter of the system is varied, such as the diameter of the wire or an applied magnetic field. The nature of the transition generally depends on the structure of the nanowire and the unwanted noise from the environment. A new fabrication technique will be developed in order to achieve precise control of the microstructure of the nanowires. The coupling with the environment will be purposely introduced in a controlled and tunable way in order to study its effect on the quantum properties of the nanowires. These nanowires will represent an experimental realization of a model system for investigating the general behavior of quantum systems interacting with the environment. Besides advancing our understanding of the fundamental physics of mesoscopic superconductors and quantum systems in general, this project will serve to prepare graduate and undergraduate students for scientific careers, develop new web-based teaching tools, provide research opportunities to high school students and teachers, and build a solid basis for future research. 


Technical Abstract
The goal of this Faculty Early Career Development project at Johns Hopkins University is to investigate the quantum phase transitions and dissipation in superconducting nanowires. Quantum phase transitions occur at the absolute zero of temperature and are driven by quantum fluctuations of some parameter, such as the diameter of the wire or a magnetic field. A new fabrication technique will be developed in order to achieve a precise control of the physical properties of the nanowires and special attention will be paid to investigating the effects of an applied magnetic field, and the details of transport in the non-superconducting regime. A cryostat with a dilution refrigerator and the appropriate filtering arrangements will be used to minimize the unwanted noise from the environment. The coupling with the environment will then be introduced in a controlled and tunable way, in order to study its impact on the quantum effects in the nanowires. Realizing tunable dissipation and coupling it into a superconducting nanowire will provide an important model system for investigating the general behavior of quantum systems interacting with the environment. Besides advancing our understanding of the fundamental physics of mesoscopic superconductors and quantum systems in general, this project will serve to prepare graduate and undergraduate students for scientific careers, develop new web-based teaching tools, provide research opportunities to high school students and teachers, and build a solid basis for future research.

por.por_cntn:
On length scales of several nanometers (billionths of a meter), the behavior of electrons is determined entirely by quantum physics. The quantum nature of electrons provides numerous opportunities for truly transformative applications, such as quantum computing and spin-based electronics. In order to make new quantum technologies possible, it is necessary to be able to create, manipulate and measure quantum states of electrons in a controlled and reproducible way. A major impediment to this endeavor is the inevitable presence of the electromagnetic environment (including the background radiation from various sources and the measurement setup itself), which tends to change quantum systems in unpredictable ways. Understanding the quantum behavior of electronic systems and the effects of their electromagnetic environment will pave the way toward the development of novel quantum devices.

This Faculty Early Career Development project at Johns Hopkins University investigated the quantum behavior of electrons in one-dimensional nanowires. As the temperature is decreased close to absolute zero, quantum phase transitions between a superconducting and an insulating state were observed. These transitions occurred when some critical parameter of the system was varied, such as the diameter of the wire, impurity doping, microstructure, or an applied magnetic field. The nature of the transition generally depended on the structure of the nanowire. A new fabrication technique was developed in order to achieve precise control of the size, shape and the microstructure of the nanowires. The interaction with the environment was purposely introduced in a controlled and tunable way in order to study its effect on the quantum properties of the nanowires. It was found that the electromagnetic environment (electrical resistance in the measurement leads, contact resistance, screening of electrons, high-frequency noise, etc) has a profound effect on the quantum phase transitions, changing many of the critical parameters in a systematic way.

These findings are of crucial importance for the development of quantum device technologies, but they also have considerable fundamental importance: the studied nanowires represent an experimental realization of a model system for investigating the general behavior of quantum systems interacting with the environment. Besides advancing our understanding of the fundamental physics of nanoscale superconductors and quantum systems in general, this project prepared four graduate students and ten undergraduate students for scientific careers, developed new web-based teaching tools, provided numerous research opportunities to high school students and teachers, developed fabrication tools, implemented new characterization and measurement infrastructure and built a solid basis for future research.
